OST Official | released = 28 April 2010 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Soundtrack]] | length = | label = [[Walt Disney Records|Walt Disney]], [[Avex Group|Avex]] | producer = | chronology = ''[[Lilo & Stitch (franchise)|Lilo & Stitch]]'' music | prev_title = [[Leroy & Stitch#Soundtrack|Lilo & Stitch Hawaiian Album]] | prev_year = 2006 | next_title = | next_year = }} {{nihongo|'''''Stitch!: Original Soundtrack'''''|スティッチ！オリジナル・サウンドトラック|Sutitchi! Orijinaru Saundotorakku}} is a collection of opening, insert, and ending songs based on ''Stitch!''. It was released on April 28, 2010. '''Track list:'''{{cite web|url=http://www.disney.co.jp/records/stitch/tv/index.html|title=ミュージック｜ディズニー｜Disney.jp ｜|work=disney.co.jp}} # {{nihongo|"Minamikaze to Taiyō"|南風と太陽||"South Wind & Sun"}} by [[Mongol800]] # "Rodeo star mate" by [[The Pillows]] # "SMILE" by [[Kimaguren]] # {{nihongo|"Ichariba Ohana"|イチャリバオハナ||"If We've Met Before, We're [[Ohana]]"}} by [[Begin (band)|Begin]] # {{nihongo|"Aoi Arashi"|アオイアラシ||"Blue Storm"}} by [[All Japan Goith]] # "TOMODACHI" (Friends) by [[Glean Piece]] # "HERO" by Kiyotaka Ishikawa # {{nihongo|"Hitori Janai"|ひとりじゃない||"You Are Not Alone"}} by Bless4 # "Number One" by LoversSoul # {{nihongo|"Kagen no Tsuki"|下弦の月||"Waning Moon"}} by Chihiro Kamiya # {{Nihongo|"Stitch is Coming"|スティッチ・イズ・カミング|Sutitchi Izu Kamingu}} by [[Bless4]] # {{Nihongo|"Stitch [[Eisa (dance)|Eisa]]"|スティッチ・エイサー|Sutitchi Eisaa}} by LoversSoul # {{nihongo|"Izayoi Yoi"|イザヨイヨイ||"Izayoi Evening"}} by [[Begin (band)|Begin]] featuring Kanako Hatoma == Theme songs == === Stitch! (Season 1) === ;Opening theme: *{{Nihongo|"Ichariba Ohana"|イチャリバオハナ||"If We've Met Before, We're [[Ohana]]"}} by [[Begin (band)|Begin]] ;Ending themes: *{{Nihongo|"Izayoi Yoi"|イザヨイヨイ||"Izayoi Evening"}} by [[Begin (band)|Begin]] w/ Kanako Hatoma (ep 1 - 13) *"Stitch is Coming" by [[Bless4]] (ep 14 - 26) ;Insert themes: *{{nihongo|"Hitori Janai"|ひとりじゃない||"You Are Not Alone"}} by [[Bless4]] === Stitch! ~The Mischievous Alien's Great Adventure~ (Season 2) === ;Opening theme: * "SMILE" by Kimaguren (ep 1 - 10) * "Rodeo star mate" by [[The Pillows]] (ep 11 - 19) * {{Nihongo|"Minami Kaze to Taiyou"|南風と太陽||"South Wind & Sun"}} by [[Mongol800]]{{cite web|url=http://www.tv-asahi.co.jp/stitch/news/cur/index.html|title=テレビ朝日｜スティッチ！〜ずっと最高のトモダチ〜|work=tv-asahi.co.jp}} (ep 20 - 29) ;Ending theme: * {{nihongo|"Stitch [[Eisa (dance)|Eisa]]"|スティッチ・エイサー|Sutitchi Eisaa}} by LoversSoul ;Insert Song: * "Waning Moon" by Chihiro Kamiya * "Number One" by LoversSoul * "Tomodachi" by Gleam Piece * "Aoi Arashi" by All Japan Goith * "Hero" by Ishikawa Kiyotaka === Stitch! ~Best Friends Forever~ (Season 3) === ;Opening theme: * {{nihongo|"Minna no Yume"|みんなのゆめ||"Everybody's Dream"}} by Mariko Kojima featuring Chihiro Ozawa ; Ending theme * {{nihongo|"Minna Stitch Tomodachi!"|みんなスティッチともだち!||"Everyone Stitch The Friends!"}} by SYUHEI ([[Disney Channel Japan]] Only) ==Broadcast== The series airs on [[Seven Network]], [[7mate]], [[7Two]], and [[Disney Channel (Australia and New Zealand)|Disney Channel]] in [[Australia]], on [[Disney Channel]] in [[Singapore]] and [[India]], on [[Toon Disney (Italy)|Toon Disney]] in [[Italy]], on [[TV3 (Malaysia)|TV3]] and [[TV2 (Malaysia)|TV2]] in [[Malaysia]], on [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]] in the [[Philippines]], on [[RTÉ Two]] in [[Ireland]], and on [[Disney Cinemagic]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. The first season began airing in English on [[Disney Channel (Australia)|the Australian Disney Channel]] on 4 December 2009, and later on [[Disney Channel Asia]] 19 December 2009. The first season premièred on [[Disney Channel Latin America]] on 2 May 2010, in the American Spanish dub. The second season aired on [[Disney Channel Latin America]] on 6 June 2011. The third season aired on [[Disney Channel Latin America]] on 20 August 2012.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OxUC-E55lvg&list=UUk_57qXIuK1OrkfzdkyNxEA&index=2&feature=plcp|title=¡Stitch! Tercera Temporada Episodio 1 "Nuevo Hogar" Español Latino|date=20 August 2012|work=YouTube}}{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=toHGTDO7c9c|title=¡Stitch! 3x01 Creditos Finales Español Latino|date=20 August 2012|work=YouTube}} The first season also aired on Finland's Disney Channel 7 June 2010, subtitled in Finnish with English dub. The anime has also aired in other Scandinavian countries on The Disney Channel, on [[Disney Cinemagic (UK & Ireland)|Disney Cinemagic]] in the UK, and on [[Toon Disney (Italy)|Toon Disney]] in Italy. The Dutch version aired on Disney XD Netherlands and Disney Channel Netherlands as well as on the Disney Channel in Belgium. On October 24, 2011, the series began airing on [[Disney XD]] in the United States, but was removed from the schedule five days later due to unknown reasons,{{cite web|title=Stitch! Anime No Longer Listed on Disney XD|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2011-10-28/stitch-anime-no-longer-listed-on-disney-xd|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=August 31, 2016|date=October 28, 2011}} leaving the series unfinished in the country. As a result, it has only five episodes aired in the U.S. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == === Official Japanese sites === * [http://www.disney.co.jp/tv/dc/program/anime/stitch.html Disney's ''Stitch!'' website on Disney Channel Japan] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080905072555/http://www.disney.co.jp/character/stitch/hawaii/ Disney's Stitch character page (Hawaii)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080905072600/http://www.disney.co.jp/character/stitch/okinawa/ Disney's Stitch character page (Okinawa)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090816181231/http://www.tv-asahi.co.jp/stitch/ Official TV Asahi page of Stitch! ~Zutto Saikou no Tomodachi~] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101124032512/http://www.tv-asahi.co.jp/stitch2009/ Official TV Asahi page of Stitch! ~Itazura Alien no Daibouken~] * [http://www.tv-tokyo.co.jp/anime/stitch/ Official TV Tokyo page of Stitch!] === International sites === * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101025003924/http://www.disney-stitch.co.kr/ Official Korean site] (archive) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100406021316/http://www.stitchontheloose.com.hk/ Official Cantonese site] (archive) ===Others=== * {{IMDb title|1409066}} * {{ann|anime|10252}} * [http://www.saveliloandstitch.org/japan.php ''Stitch!'' on SaveLiloAndStitch.org] {{Lilo & Stitch}} {{Madhouse}} {{Shin-Ei Animation}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stitch}} [[Category:Lilo & Stitch]] [[Category:2008 anime television series]] [[Category:2009 Japanese television series endings]] [[Category:2009 anime television series]] [[Category:2010 Japanese television series endings]] [[Category:2010 anime television series]] [[Category:2011 Japanese television series endings]] [[Category:Disney animated television series]] [[Category:Madhouse (company)]] [[Category:Shin-Ei Animation]] [[Category:TV Tokyo shows]] [[Category:TV Asahi shows]] [[Category:Television shows set in Hawaii]] [[Category:Television programs based on films]] [[Category:Television series based on Disney films]] [[Category:Sequel television series]]

page.title: The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title = The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion |image = The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius - Jet Fusion Coverart.png | alt = North American GameCube cover art |caption = North American GameCube cover art |developer = [[Helixe]] (GBA), [[BigSky Interactive, Inc.]] (PS2, GC) |publisher = [[THQ]]
[[Nickelodeon|Nick Games]] |released = '''GameCube'''{{cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/console/gamecube/data/915360.html |title=Jimmy Neutron: Jet Fusion Release Information for GameCube |publisher=[[GameFAQs]] |accessdate=2009-03-10}} & '''PS2'''{{cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/console/ps2/data/915364.html |title=Jimmy Neutron: Jet Fusion Release Information for PlayStation 2 |publisher=[[GameFAQs]] |accessdate=2009-03-10}}
{{vgrelease|NA|September 16, 2003|PAL|November 21, 2003}}'''Game Boy Advance'''{{cite web|url=http://www.gamefaqs.com/portable/gbadvance/data/915363.html |title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion Release Information for Game Boy Advance |publisher=[[GameFAQs]] |accessdate=2009-03-10}}
{{vgrelease|NA|September 24, 2003|PAL|November 21, 2003}} |genre = [[Action adventure game|Action-adventure]]
[[Side-scrolling video game|2D platform]] (GBA) |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = [[Game Boy Advance]]
[[GameCube]]
[[PlayStation 2]] }} '''''The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius: Jet Fusion''''' is a [[video game]] released in 2003 based on the animated TV series ''[[The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius]]'' as well as the [[telefilm]] of the same name. In the game, the player controls Jimmy Neutron who has to save the movie star/spy Jet Fusion by using a variety of gadgets and inventions. An [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] version was planned, but ultimately cancelled due to the low sales of the game. ==Plot== Jimmy has an assignment to write a book report, and Jimmy decides to invent the Virtual World Reproduction Machine (VWRM), a device that will show the class what the book is about like a movie. Jimmy places his Jet Fusion book into the machine and it malfunctions, thus turning Retroville into a virtual world. Then Professor Calamitous kidnaps Jet Fusion and it's up to Jimmy to save him. Throughout the game, the player has to collect pieces for major and minor inventions, which help Jimmy continue to the next level. The one major invention in each level helps defeat the boss in the boss level, while the one minor invention in each world helps Jimmy battle his enemies and various obstacles. The minor inventions also come with a primary and secondary action. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GBA = true | NGC = true | PS2 = true | CVG_GBA = 3.7/10 | GameZone_GBA = 6.9/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/reviews/2003/10/13/jimmy_neutron_jet_fusion_gba_review |title=Jimmy Neutron Jet Fusion - GBA - Review |last=Bedigian |first=Louis |publisher=GameZone |date=2003-10-13 |accessdate=2013-12-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604052507/http://gameboy.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r21504_GBA.htm |archivedate=2009-06-04 |deadurl=no}} | GameZone_NGC = 7/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/reviews/2003/10/18/the_adventures_of_jimmy_neutron_boy_genius_jet_fusion_gc_review |title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion - GC - Review |last=Hollingshead |first=Anise |publisher=GameZone |date=2013-10-18 |accessdate=2013-12-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926164844/http://gamecube.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r21504.htm |archivedate=2008-09-26 |deadurl=no}} | GameZone_PS2 = 5/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/reviews/2003/10/13/the_adventures_of_jimmy_neutron_boy_genius_jet_fusion_ps2_review |title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion - PS2 - Review |last=Bedigian |first=Louis |publisher=GameZone |date=2003-10-13 |accessdate=2013-12-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024065858/http://ps2.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r21504.htm |archivedate=2008-10-24 |deadurl=no}} | IGN_GBA = 5.5/10{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2003/10/10/jimmy-neutron-jet-fusion |title=Jimmy Neutron: Jet Fusion (GBA) |last=Harris |first=Craig |publisher=IGN |date=2003-10-10 |accessdate=2013-12-22}} | IGN_NGC = 6.1/10{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2003/09/23/jimmy-neutron-jet-fusion-review |title=Jimmy Neutron: Jet Fusion Review (GCN) |last=Irwin |first=Mary Jane |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=2003-09-22 |accessdate=2013-12-22}} | IGN_PS2 = 6.1/10{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2003/09/23/the-adventures-of-jimmy-neutron-boy-genius-jet-fusion |title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron, Boy Genius: Jet Fusion (PS2) |last=Irwin |first=Mary Jane |publisher=IGN |date=2003-09-22 |accessdate=2013-12-22}} | NGC_NGC = 71%{{cite journal|title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion (GC) |magazine=[[NGC Magazine]] |date=January 2004}} | NP_GBA = 3/5{{cite journal|title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion (GBA) |magazine=Nintendo Power |date=December 2003 |page=150}} | NP_NGC = 3.2/5{{cite journal|title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion (GC) |magazine=[[Nintendo Power]] |date=December 2003 |page=144}} | OPMUK_PS2 = 5/10{{cite journal|title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion |magazine=[[PlayStation Official Magazine - UK|Official UK PlayStation 2 Magazine]] |date=December 2003}} | GR_GBA = 57.80%{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/gba/915363-the-adventures-of-jimmy-neutron-boy-genius-jet-fusion/index.html |title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion for Game Boy Advance |publisher=GameRankings |accessdate=2013-12-22}} | GR_NGC = 63%{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/gamecube/915360-jimmy-neutron-jet-fusion/index.html |title=Jimmy Neutron: Jet Fusion for GameCube |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=2013-12-22}} | GR_PS2 = 50.75%{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps2/915364-jimmy-neutron-jet-fusion/index.html |title=Jimmy Neutron: Jet Fusion for PlayStation 2 |publisher=GameRankings |accessdate=2013-12-22}} | MC_GBA = 61/100{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/game-boy-advance/the-adventures-of-jimmy-neutron-boy-genius-jet-fusion |title=The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion for Game Boy Advance Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=2013-12-22}} | MC_NGC = 60/100{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/gamecube/jimmy-neutron-jet-fusion |title=Jimmy Neutron: Jet Fusion for GameCube Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=2013-12-22}} | MC_PS2 = 50/100{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/jimmy-neutron-jet-fusion |title=Jimmy Neutron: Jet Fusion for PlayStation 2 Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=2013-12-22}} }} Reception of the game was mixed. [[GameRankings]] gave it a score of 63% for the GameCube version, 50.75% for the PlayStation 2 version, and 57.80% for the Game Boy Advance version; while [[Metacritic]] gave it a score of 60 out of 100 for the GameCube version, 50 out of 100 for the PS2 version, and 61 out of 100 for the GBA version. {{-}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adventures Of Jimmy Neutron Boy Genius: Jet Fusion}} [[Category:2003 video games]] [[Category:Action-adventure games]] [[Category:Cancelled Xbox games]] [[Category:GameCube games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:Game Boy Advance games]] [[Category:The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius video games|Jet Fusion]] [[Category:Krome Studios games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] {{Action-adventure-videogame-stub}}

{{Infobox video game series |title = The ClueFinders |image = File:The ClueFinders.jpg |caption =The four members of the Cluefinders team: Leslie, Santiago, Owen, and Joni. The inclusion of four races in the main cast has been pointed out by many critics. |genre = [[Educational entertainment|Edutainment]] |developer = [[The Learning Company]] |publisher = The Learning Company ([[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]]) |platform of origin = |year of inception = January, 1998<ref name="CF-TopTen">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-cluefinders-series-makes-the-list-of-top-10-additions-to-the-computer-museums-best-software-for-kids-gallery-77215622.html|title=The ClueFinders Series Makes the List of Top 10 Additions to The Computer Museum's Best Software for Kids Gallery|website=PR Newswire|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref> |first release version = ''[[The ClueFinders 3rd Grade Adventures: The Mystery of Mathra]]'' |first release date = January, 1998<ref name="CF-TopTen"/> |latest release version = ''[[The ClueFinders: Mystery Mansion Arcade]]'' |latest release date = 2002 }}
'''''The ClueFinders''''' is a series of educational software aimed at children aged eight to twelve. The series was created by [[The Learning Company]] as a counterpart to their ''[[Reader Rabbit]]'' series for older elementary-aged students and features a band of mystery-solving teens. The series has received praise for its balance of education and entertainment and has won numerous awards.
== History ==
=== The Learning Company era (1997-2001) === ClueFInders was conceived as a continuation of the ''Reader Rabbit'' series, appealing to the older 3rd-6th grade level.<ref name="CF-LANews">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/aug/30/news/tt-40015|title=An Education in Child's Play|last=Shannon|first=L. R.|date=August 30, 2001|access-date=2017-02-06|issn=0362-4331|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times}}</ref> The first ''ClueFinders'' title, ''[[The ClueFinders 3rd Grade Adventures: The Mystery of Mathra|The ClueFinders 3rd Grade Adventures]],'' was released in 1998 and most of the subsequent games were released within the next two years.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} ''The ClueFinders' 4th Grade Adventures''<nowiki/>' was announced on July 13, 1998.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-learning-company-inc-extends-its-cluefinders-line-of-grade-based-software-with-the-cluefinders-4th-grade-adventures-75714972.html|title=The Learning Company, Inc. Extends Its ClueFinders' Line of Grade-Based Software With 'The ClueFinders' 4th Grade Adventures'|last=Inc.|first=The Learning Company,|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-04-04}}</ref> Later that year, The Learning Company used Cluefinders<nowiki/>' 4th Grade Adventures as the prototype for Internet Applet technology that allowed users to download supplementary activities from the Cluefinders website.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1998-11-02|title=INTERNET APPLET PROTOTYPE SEAMLESSLY INTEGRATES WITH CD-ROM COMPONENTS.|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-53159078.html}}</ref> Six games were released across 1998-1999, while 2000 and 2001 each saw one new ''ClueFinders'' game.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} These releases were followed by noneducational bonus discs.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} ''Cluefinders'' held a writing competition in 2001.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://promotions2.marketsystems.net/cluefinders/default.html|title=Hello|website=web-beta.archive.org|access-date=2017-03-30|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010802032137/http://promotions2.marketsystems.net/cluefinders/default.html|archivedate=2001-08-02|df=}}</ref> Sponsored by The Learning Company, the competition was open to 3rd-6th grade classrooms in the United States. The winning essay - a new adventure for the ClueFinders crew, won an iMac.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2000-11-26|title=Holiday sites are full of fun and games.(Arts and Lifestyle)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-67309546.html}}</ref> In 1998, The Learning Company was acquired by Mattel for $3.7 billion, considered one of the worst deals in business history; the following year Mattel sold off their The Learning Company assets to Gores Technology Group.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/4467013/Mattel-sale-ends-3.6bn-fiasco.html|title=Mattel sale ends $3.6bn fiasco|last=York|first=By Andrew Cave in New|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-03-31|language=en}}</ref> 2000's ''[[The ClueFinders 4th grade adventures:]]'' was the first to include the A.D.A.P.T technology, which allowed teachers and parents to monitor the player's progress and included auto-adjustable levels based on the player's ability.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o9VxCBx7ta4C&pg=PA232&dq=cluefinders&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiL08WBmIvTAhVGgLwKHRocBDQQ6AEIHjAB#v=onepage&q=cluefinders&f=false|title=PC Mag|last=Inc|first=Ziff Davis|date=2000-09-01|publisher=Ziff Davis, Inc.|language=en}}</ref> In the year 2000, [[Mattel Interactive]] hired professional writers [[Jill Gorey]] and [[Barbara Herndon]] had designed a concept for a TV series, however, the franchise never made its way to television.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/mattel-interactive-enters-into-new-media-with-its-award-winning-cluefinders-brand-72498432.html|title=Mattel Interactive Enters Into New Media With Its Award-Winning ClueFinders Brand|website=PR Newswire|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref>
=== Riverdeep/HMH era (2001-present) === In 2001, Riverdeep acquired many of The Learning Company's properties from Gores Technology Group by selling $40 million in stock.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2001-11-01|title=Riverdeep acquires assets of The Learning Company. (News).(Brief Article)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-80772519.html}}</ref> Carmen Sandiego, ClueFinders, and Reader Rabbit were then licensed to the KidsEdge Website in 2002 where they were available to play among 170 games and activities.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2003-02-23|title=Impressive array of content gives KidsEdge a boost.(Arts and Lifestyle)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-97983973.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2003-03-13|title=Cossacks ride again|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1N1-0FEBFD9A64360B00.html}}</ref> In 2003, The ClueFinders' Reading Adventures was reconfigured to run on Windows XP.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/197195829/|title=Battle Creek Enquirer from Battle Creek, Michigan on May 13, 2003 · Page 15|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en}}</ref> The 2004 RCN InterACTION service allowed parents to stream over 35 games in series such as Carmen Sandiego, Clifford the Big Red Dog and ClueFinders over a broadband connection.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2004-10-12|title=Bulletin board|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1555052.html}}</ref> [[Product bundling|Compilations]] including multiple previously released titles, such as ''Cluefinders Adventure Pack and ''Cluefinders Triple Pack' have since been created{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} as well as [[Product bundling|bundled]] which includes a single ClueFinders title (often "The ClueFinders Reading Adventures") among other games (mostly other Learning Company games) in series such as "Adventure Workshop" and "After School Clubhouse".{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} In addition, the 3rd till 6th grade titles were re-released on the [[iOS]] platform on December 19, 2010.<ref name="Apple">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/cluefinders-3rd-grade/id405950720?mt=12|website=iTunes|publisher=Apple|accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref> Around this time,<ref name="Apple"/> [[LeapFrog Enterprises]] created three [[Browser game]]s, which cast different voice actors. As of 2017, [[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]] (the successor of Riverdeep) is offering the Cluefinders brand as a licensing opportunity on its website.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hmhco.com/at-home/featured-shops/the-learning-company/licensing-opportunities|title=Licensing Opportunities|website=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref>
<!-- *Adventure Kit, Scooby-Doo Minigames *http://www.mackiev.com/cluefinders/index.html Software Mackiev published ClueFinders http://events.sys-con.com/node/486813 *Mackiev + Broderbund (Windows / Macintosh hybrid) -->
== Design ==
=== Plot === Development of the games' "super compelling" and "rich" backstory took 16 months.<ref name="CF-LANews" /> The ClueFinders' adventures take place in the contemporary real world incorporating some elements of [[fantasy]] and [[science fiction]], with merely the continued presence of LapTrap pushing the series into the realm of science fiction. They simultaneously had a sense of urgency toward an end goal while allowing players to explore and use their minds on puzzles.<ref name="CF-LANews" /> Nevertheless, the opening titles from ''The ClueFinders 5th Grade Adventures'' place the series in the [[present day]]. The main cast of "complex" and "flawed" characters include ClueFinders founder and tomboy Joni, skater dude Owen, mechanically-minded Santiago, literary-minded Leslie, artificial intelligent LapTrap, and intelligent dog Socrates.<ref name="CF-LANews" /> They were chosen to be around the same age as the players after the art director ran various character designs by a group of kids; unsuccessful designs included animals, rock stars, FBI agents, which came across as babysitters instead of teammates.<ref name="CF-LANews" /> They were designed with distinct personalities and with identifiable faults to increase their relatability.<ref name="auto"/> The developers used a character grid to aid their writing; it contained information such as: "their flaws, their fears, how they met, where they grew up, and their likely reactions to certain situations".<ref name="CF-LANews" />
=== Gameplay === The series consists of "Multisubject by grade" programs, in which players practice skills and advance understanding of grade-based content.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=64BdAqI3BdkC&pg=PA184&dq=%22ClueFinders%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj6pcHhsv7SAhUnj1QKHRl3BqsQ6AEINTAG#v=onepage&q=%22ClueFinders%22&f=false|title=Teaching for Student Learning: Becoming a Master Teacher|last=Ryan|first=Kevin|last2=Cooper|first2=James M.|last3=Tauer|first3=Susan|date=2012-01-01|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=1111833605|language=en}}</ref> The player can choose to play the adventure mode or to play the game's activities outside the adventure in "practice mode." Choosing to play the adventure will lead to a follow-up sequence which further establishes the premise as well as the overall goal of the game. The bulk of each game involves traveling between different screens in a predetermined area which has various educational activities. The user will have to play these games to advance. Most of the time, each area will have one activity that needs to be completed to advance onwards, but which can only be played by collecting items from all the other activities in the area. In all the games except for ''The ClueFinders 4th Grade Adventures'', the ClueFinders are split into two teams at the start. A portable red [[videophone]] allows the two teams to make contact with each other and clicking on the phone provides the user with game hints from the other team. The other team will typically either be serving as backup, looking for clues, or else be captured and in need of rescue.
=== Graphics and coding === During the gameplay, [[2D computer graphics]] are used in the style of hand-drawn [[animated cartoon]]s with animations that use thick outlines and solid colors on two-dimensional backgrounds. For this reason, the series is often<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.superkids.com/aweb/pages/reviews/reading/7/cfra/merge.shtml|title=SuperKids Software Review of Clue Finders Reading Adventures.|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://auctions.yahoo.com/i:Clue%20Finders%20-%204th%20Grade%20Adventures%20-%20The%20Learning%20Com:5392175 Yahoo! Auctions - Clue Finders - 4th Grade Adventures - The Learning Com]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parents-choice.org/product.cfm?product_id=7085&award=xx&from=2002%20Parents'%20Choice%20Award%20Winners|title=ClueFinders: The Incredible Toy Store Adventure|publisher=}}</ref> described as imitating the look of a [[Saturday morning cartoon]] ''[[Scooby-Doo]]'' being repeatedly cited by reviewers. Cutscenes, however, use [[pre-rendered]] [[3D computer graphics|3D graphics]].
=== Educational goals === While Reader Rabbit was popular with younger audiences, the Learning Company came up with ClueFinders to appeal to third graders onward for both boys and girls. To coincide with kids' abstract thinking, the games were activity-centered and included cross-curriculum topics more sophisticated than preschool material, which included algebra, grammar and spelling. To ensure that users actually learned something, the educational content came first before the puzzles, gameplay, and objectives.<ref name="CF-LANews"/> Andy Young, vice president of product marketing for The Learning Company, noted that the ClueFinders series aimed to show children that it was "cool to be smart".<ref name="auto"/> The A.D.A.P.T. Learning Technology was introduced into The ClueFinders titles in 1999; the system contained a series of customisable features that would facilitate the player's learning by '''''A'''''ssessing abilities, '''''D'''''eveloping skills, '''''A'''''djusting levels, '''''P'''''roviding help, and '''''T'''''racking progress.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/new-adapt-learning-technologytm-helps-kids-get-the-most-out-of-their-software-experience-74942522.html|title=New A.D.A.P.T. Learning Technology(TM) Helps Kids Get the Most Out of Their Software Experience|last=Company|first=The Learning|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-06}}</ref>

ClueFinders: Mystery of the Monkey Kingdom''''' **[[Windows]], [[Macintosh]] (2001) </small> *[[MacOS]] (2010) |- |''[[The ClueFinders 4th Grade Adventures: Puzzle of the Pyramid]]'' Titled ''The === Compilations === {| class="wikitable" !Title !Year !Games |- |''ClueFinders Adventure Pack''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/games/the-cluefinders-adventure-pack/pc-800928|title=The ClueFinders: Adventure Pack (PC)|publisher=}}</ref> |2003 | *The ClueFinders Search and Solve Adventures: The Phantom Amusement Park *The ClueFinders: The Incredible Toy Store Adventure! *The ClueFinders Reading Adventures: Mystery of the Missing Amulet |- |''ClueFinders Triple Pack''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cybersoftware.co.uk/dorling_kindersley_cluefinders.shtml|title=Dorling kindersley Clue finders Year 3,4,5 and Cluefinders 6|first=Cybersoftware educational|last=software|publisher=}}</ref> |2005 | *The ClueFinders 3rd Grade Adventures: The Mystery of Mathra *The ClueFinders 4th Grade Adventures: Puzzle of the Pyramid *The ClueFinders 5th Grade Adventures: The Secret of the Living Volcano |- |''Cluefinders Math Learning System''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mac.softpedia.com/get/Educational/ClueFinders-Math-Adventures.shtml|title=ClueFinders Math Adventures Download Mac|publisher=}}</ref> |2007 | |}
=== Books and fan fiction === Two ''ClueFinders'' books, ''The Mystery of Microsneezia'' and ''The Mystery of the Backlot Banshee'', were written by [[Ellen Weiss]] and illustrated by Mel Friedman.
[[FanFiction.Net]] currently has exactly eighteen stories featuring the ClueFinders, and a ClueFinders section was added to Games in 2010.<ref>[http://www.fanfiction.net/game/ClueFinders/ ClueFinders FanFiction Archive]. FanFiction. Retrieved on 2013-09-05.</ref>
=== Other Languages === * French (titled "Le Club Des Trouvetout"). These French versions were distributed/published by The Learning Company subsidiary TLC-Edusoft.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t91WAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Le+Club+Des+Trouvetout%22&dq=%22Le+Club+Des+Trouvetout%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiVm8eHvojTAhWJQpQKHYM4DtsQ6AEIJDAC|title=Letopis Matice srpske|date=2001-01-01|publisher=Editions professionnelles du livre|language=fr}}</ref> * German (titled "Die Schlaue Bande") * Portuguese (titled "Os Caça-Pistas") * Dutch (titled "Junior Detectives") * Russian (titled "Следопыты") * Spanish (titled "Los Pequeños Exploradores")
== Reception == ''[[Computer Shopper (US magazine)|Computer Shopper]]'' and ''SuperKids'' described ''3rd Grade Adventures'' as the educational equivalent of the Indiana Jones trilogy,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.superkids.com/aweb/pages/reviews/multisub/3rdgrade/1/clue3/merge.shtml|title=The Clue Finders 3rd Grade Adventures.|last=|first=|date=|website=SuperKids Software|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=May 1, 1998|year=|title=The ClueFinders' 3rd Grade Adventures|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-20507203.html|journal=Computer Shopper|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> while the Chicago Tribune thought the "hip environmental mystery" eased children into applying their thinking and thinking skills through its mystery, animation, and challenges, commenting that it "shines in almost every way".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-05-07/features/9805070389_1_learners-rainforest-computers|title=Babes In Toyland|work=tribunedigital-chicagotribune|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en}}</ref> ''Kiplinger's Personal Finance thought [[The ClueFinders 4th Grade Adventures: Puzzle of the Pyramid|4th Grade Adventures]]'' "works hard for its players' enjoyment".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Kv4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA101&dq=cluefinders&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjBnsqmmYvTAhXIi7wKHaD5BHU4FBDoAQg6MAc#v=onepage&q=cluefinders&f=false|title=Kiplinger's Personal Finance|last=Inc|first=Kiplinger Washington Editors|date=2017-04-04|publisher=Kiplinger Washington Editors, Inc.|language=en}}</ref> ''[[Discovery Education]] wrote that 5th Grade Adventures "seamlessly combines fun and learning".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://school.discoveryeducation.com/parents/reviewcorner/software/cf5thgrade.html|title=The ClueFinders 5th Grade Adventures|last=|first=|date=|website=Discovery Education|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref>'' ''SuperKids'' praised the "cartoon quality animation and an alluring storyline" of ''Math Adventures'', and the Cluedo-inspired gameplay.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.superkids.com/aweb/pages/reviews/math/5/cfmath/merge.shtml|title=The ClueFinders' Math Ages 9-12|last=|first=|date=|website=SuperKids Software|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref> 01Net asserted that in terms of ''[[The ClueFinders 5th Grade Adventures: The Secret of the Living Volcano|5th Grade Adventures]]'', the activities take precedence over the merely incidental storyline;<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.01net.com/astuces/le-club-des-trouvetout-lenigme-du-volcan-114264.html|title=Le club des TrouveTout, l'énigme du volcan|last=01net|work=01net|access-date=2017-04-03|language=fr-FR}}</ref> in 2001 the site described the series' graphics as "very colorful" and "truly seductive"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.01net.com/actualites/le-club-des-trouvetout-laventure-du-savoir-166286.html|title=Le club des TrouveTout : L'aventure du savoir|last=01net|work=01net|access-date=2017-04-03|language=fr-FR}}</ref> but three years later the site decided they were outdated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.01net.com/astuces/le-club-des-trouvetout-les-plantes-carnivores-250407.html|title=Le Club des Trouvetout : les plantes carnivores|last=01net|work=01net|access-date=2017-04-03|language=fr-FR}}</ref> Asbury Park Press noted that ''[[The ClueFinders Reading Adventures|Reading Adventures]], like [[Carmen Sandiego Word Detective]],'' "place[d] reading games in the middle of mysteries".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/145931263/|title=Asbury Park Press from Asbury Park, New Jersey on May 13, 2003 · Page 43|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en}}</ref> ''Teach'' thought the ''Search and Solve Adventures'' mystery was engaging, and that the game successfully combined storytelling with problem-solving activities,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=November 1, 2009|year=|title=ClueFinders Search and Solve Adventures|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1944519501.html|journal=Teach|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> while PC Mag thought it was "mysterious", "chill-inducing", and "engrossing".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZTmyTcu2h1EC&pg=PA204&dq=cluefinders&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiL08WBmIvTAhVGgLwKHRocBDQQ6AEIPDAI#v=onepage&q=cluefinders&f=false|title=PC Mag|last=Inc|first=Ziff Davis|date=2001-01-02|publisher=Ziff Davis, Inc.|language=en}}</ref> ''[[PC Magazine (British magazine)|PC Mag]]'' liked ''The ClueFinders: The Incredible Toy Store Adventure!'''s maths, science, and language puzzles, and its adjustable levels,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2jdKbuIo44sC&pg=PA158&dq=%22ClueFinders%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj6pcHhsv7SAhUnj1QKHRl3BqsQ6AEIIzAC#v=onepage&q=%22ClueFinders%22&f=false|title=PC Mag|last=Inc|first=Ziff Davis|date=2001-12-26|publisher=Ziff Davis, Inc.|language=en}}</ref> while The New York Times praised the main cast's culturally diversity and maturity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/20/technology/basics-three-r-s-reading-writing-rebooting.html|title=BASICS; Three R's: Reading, Writing, Rebooting|last=Keim|first=Alice|date=2001-12-20|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-04|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
''Exploring Values Through Literature, Multimedia, and Literacy Events'' highlighted the series for its multicultural and balanced cast in which the nonwhite characters have equal status to the white character, noting that Leslie and Santiago are the main sources of knowledge, though noted there were no examples of software with the primary character being non-white.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=djgoFoEQ6poC&pg=PA87&dq=cluefinders&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjD_MSllovTAhUKhrwKHWxMBJcQ6AEIKjAE#v=onepage&q=cluefinders&f=false|title=Exploring Values Through Literature, Multimedia, and Literacy Events: Making Connections|last=Schmidt|first=Patricia Ruggiano|last2=Pailliotet|first2=Ann Watts|date=2008-01-01|publisher=IAP|isbn=9781593119454|language=en}}</ref> Meanwhile, while ''[[Boston Herald|The Boston Herald]]'' commented the series had "come a long way", the paper suggested that the decision to include a Caucasian (Joni), Asian (Owen), Black (Leslie), and Latino (Santiago) in its main cast smelt of interference from the California School Board standard.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|date=2002-05-05|title=ClueFinders uncover much frustration.(Arts and Lifestyle)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-85458459.html}}</ref> The paper praised the series' "television-quality animation, broad educational focus and lively situations", though thought the early games were uneven in difficulty.<ref name=":0" /> ''Exploring Values Through Literature, Multimedia, and Literacy Events'' further praised the series' focus on character interdependence; how missions are not successful until and unless they work together.<ref name=":1" /> ''Children's Software Review'' managing editor Ellen Wolock criticised The Learning Company for focusing too much of its resources on repackaging its old software, commenting that she received the impression the company was "just throw[ing] together" entries in its newer ClueFinders series.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2000-02-04|title=Purchase of Educational Software Maker Dragged Down Mattel.(Knight Ridder/Tribune Business News)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-59201957.html}}</ref> ''Working Mother'' thought the series offered a "painless way for kids to hone their skills".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5aA1CjS2rMcC&pg=PT66&dq=cluefinders&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiL08WBmIvTAhVGgLwKHRocBDQQ6AEIIjAC#v=onepage&q=cluefinders&f=false|title=Working Mother|last=Media|first=Working Mother|date=1999-12-01|publisher=Working Mother Media|language=en}}</ref> The Cincinnati Enquirer recommended the "strong" series to gamers who were unable to locate the then-soon-to-be-discontinued title ''[[The Sims: Livin' Large]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/102350570/|title=The Cincinnati Enquirer from Cincinnati, Ohio on October 11, 2000 · Page 62|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en}}</ref> and said "there is a lot to like" about entries in the series, such as its [[closed captioning]] of later titles.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/102594851/|title=The Cincinnati Enquirer from Cincinnati, Ohio on September 19, 2001 · Page 73|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2017-04-04|language=en}}</ref>
One piece of research used the game as a "tool for assessing how children worked on computers in social interactions and influence acceptance by peers in classroom interactions."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tdZSAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA27&dq=cluefinders&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjphLzwmIvTAhXME7wKHbQQAps4ChDoAQgpMAQ#v=onepage&q=cluefinders&f=false|title=Interactive Technologies for Autism: A Review|last=Kientz|first=Julie A.|last2=Goodwin|first2=Matthew|last3=Hayes|first3=Gillian R.|last4=Abowd|first4=Gregory D.|date=2013-11-01|publisher=Morgan & Claypool Publishers|isbn=9781608456413|language=en}}</ref>
=== Commercial performance === ''The ClueFinders' 3rd Grade Adventures'' a top ten best-selling educational title in retail stores during the months of March, April, and May.<ref name="auto"/> By 2001, the first six games had sold around 3.5 million copies.<ref name="CF-LANews"/> <!-- https://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+ClueFinders'+3rd+Grade+Adventures+Recognized+Among+the+Best...-a054061319 -->
=== Awards and nominations === {{Expand list|date=February 2017}} Since its creation in 1998, the ClueFinders series has won over 50 awards and accolades in three years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-learning-company-is-ranked--1-in-schools-71360897.html|title=The Learning Company is Ranked # 1 in Schools|website=http://www.prnewswire.com|access-date=April 5, 2017}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" !Year !Award !Recipient !Result |- |1998 |Award of Excellence |The Cluefinders 3rd Grade Adventures: The Mystery of Mathra |{{Won}}<ref name="CF-TopTen"/> |- |1998 |Thunderbeam Web site Seal of Approval |The Cluefinders 3rd Grade Adventures: The Mystery of Mathra |{{Won}}<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-learning-company-inc-extends-its-cluefinders-line-of-grade-based-software-with-the-cluefinders-4th-grade-adventures-75714972.html|title=The Learning Company, Inc. Extends Its ClueFinders' Line of Grade-Based Software With 'The ClueFinders' 4th Grade Adventures'|first=The Learning Company,|last=Inc.|publisher=}}</ref> |- |1998 |Children's Software Revue's All Star Software list |The Cluefinders 3rd Grade Adventures: The Mystery of Mathra |Featured<ref name="auto1"/> |- |1998 |Parents' Choice Award - Gold Award |The Cluefinders Math Ages 9–12 |{{Won}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parents-choice.org/product.cfm?product_id=269&StepNum=1&award=aw|title=The Cluefinders' Math Ages 9-12|website=Parents' Choice Foundation|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref> |- |1998 |Parents' Choice Award - Gold Award |The ClueFinders' 3rd Grade Adventures |{{Won}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parents-choice.org/product.cfm?product_id=511&from=Riverdeep/The%20Learning%20Company|title=The ClueFinders' 3rd Grade Adventures|website=Parents' Choice Foundation|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref> |- |2002 |Parents' Choice Award - Silver Honor |ClueFinders: The Incredible Toy Store Adventure |{{Won}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parents-choice.org/product.cfm?product_id=7085|title=ClueFinders: The Incredible Toy Store Adventure|website=Parents' Choice Foundation|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref> |}

page.title: The Mystic Nine Side Story: Flowers Bloom in February

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = The Mystic Nine Side Story: Flowers Bloom in February | image = | alt = | caption = | film name = {{Film name | Alternative name =  The Mystic Nine Side Story: Er Yuehong | simplified = 老九门番外之二月花开 | pinyin = }} | screenplay = Kennedy Xu | based on = ''[[Daomu Biji]]'' by Nanpai Sanshu | starring = [[Lay (entertainer)|Zhang Yixing]] | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|df=y|2016|10|20}} | runtime = 90 minutes | country = {{Plainlist|China}} | language = {{Plainlist|Mandarin}} | budget = | gross = | italic title = | directors = Lin Nan | producers = Bai Yicong | production companies = [[iQiyi]], [[Dragon TV]], NP Entertainment }}'''''The Mystic Nine Side Story: Flowers Bloom in February''''' ({{zh|s=老九门番外之二月花开|p=Lǎo jiǔ mén fānwài zhī èr yuè huā kāi|c=|t=|l=Old Nine Gates Flowers Bloom in February}}) is a side story of the drama ''[[The Mystic Nine]].'' The web film was co-produced by [[iQiyi]], [[Dragon Television|Dragon TV]] and [https://baike.baidu.com/item/南派泛娱有限公司 NP Entertainment] and was released on October 20, 2016''.'' This spin off is a continuation of the television series whereby it solely focuses on character Er Yuehong portrayed by [[Lay (entertainer)|Zhang Yixing (Lay)]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://baike.baidu.com/item/老九门番外之二月花开|title=老九门番外之二月花开|last=|first=|date=|work=Baidu|access-date=2016-10-20|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=Chinese}}</ref>
== Background == The side story serves as a spin off and continuation to ''[[The Mystic Nine]]'' which is a prequel to the Chinese television series ''[[The Lost Tomb]]'' based on the internet novel ''[[Daomu Biji]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asianjunkie.com/2016/05/21/exos-lay-to-star-in-old-nine-gates-the-prequel-to-a-crazy-c-drama/|title=EXO’s Lay to star in ‘Old Nine Gates’, the prequel to a crazy C-drama|last=Betsy|website=Asian Junkie|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref> The plot of the story revolves around the main character of ''[[The Mystic Nine]]'' which is Er Yuehong.
== Synopsis == The side story narrates the effort of relocating a cultural relic safeguarded beneath an ancient tomb during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War|Sino-Japanese]] era. Er Yuehong undertook this mission by approaching the tomb which on surface is a heavily pre-occupied Japanese army base. Tapping his skills for Chinese opera and utilising his connections, he performed as an opera singer while fighting off the Japanese soldiers on the other. With his wisdom and bravery, he strives with his might to recover the relic.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gd.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2016-11/02/c_1119822093_3.htm|title=老九门番外之二月花开播出时间 预告片剧情介绍|last=|first=|date=|work=XinHua Net|access-date=2016-11-02|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=Chinese}}</ref>
== Cast == * [[Lay (entertainer)|Zhang Yixing]] as Er Yuehong (二月红), second master of the mystic nine clan. An expert at tomb raiding due to his family background, but chooses to become an opera singer due to his passion. * Zhang Zheng Yang as Shenggong Weilai (神宫未来), the second in command to Qiu Shan who is ruthless and would stop at nothing to achieve victory. * Ming Zheng as Qiu Shan (秋山), a Japanese commander who harbours a deep fondness for Chinese opera and culture. * He Yujun as Ji An (吉安), friend to Er Yuehong. Perished while completing his mission. * Liu Weiling as Hong Gu (红杏), servant of Er Yuehong who accompanied him on his adventure. * Mou Yuandi as Bai Zhanmei (白湛梅), frenemy to Er Yuehong who rendered his assistance to the latter.
== Soundtrack == {{Track listing | all_writing = The Mystic Nine Side Story: Flowers Bloom in February Soundtrack | title1 = Liang Bao Hou (凉薄侯) }}
== Reception == The film streamed over 93 million views on IQiYi.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iqiyi.com/v_19rr9a8i4s.html|title=Viewers on iQiYi|last=|first=|date=|website=[[IQiyi]]|language=zh|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

{{Use British English|date=January 2011}}{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox court case | name = Chambers v Director of Public Prosecutions | court = [[High Court of Justice#Queen's Bench Division|High Court of Justice (Queen's Bench Division)]] | full name = Paul Chambers v Director of Public Prosecutions | date decided = 27 July 2012 | citations = [http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/QB/2012/2157.html [2012] EWHC 2157 (QB)] | transcripts = [http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/QB/2012/2157.html High Court transcript] | judges = [[Lord Judge| Lord Judge CJ]]
Owen J
Griffith Williams J | number of judges = 3 | appealed from = Doncaster [[Magistrates' Court (England and Wales)|Magistrates' Court]] | opinions = The message was not objectively menacing; the conviction was therefore quashed.{{cite news |title=Twitter joke trial conviction quashed in High Court |author=Martin Beckford |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/twitter/9431677/Twitter-joke-trial-conviction-quashed-in-High-Court.html |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date=27 July 2012 |accessdate=9 September 2012}} | keywords = {{flatlist | * [[Communications Act 2003]] * [[Freedom of speech]] * ''[[Mens rea]]'' * [[Twitter]] }} |italic title = no }} '''''R v Paul Chambers''''' (appealed to the High Court as '''''Chambers v Director of Public Prosecutions'''''), popularly known as the '''Twitter Joke Trial''', was a [[United Kingdom]] legal case centred on the conviction of a man under the [[Communications Act 2003]] for posting a joke about destroying an airport to [[Twitter]], a message which police regarded as "menacing". The conviction was widely condemned as a [[miscarriage of justice]],{{cite web|url=http://www.thelawyer.com/issues/online/the-twitter-bomb-hoax-case-worse-than-we-thought/|title=The Twitter "Bomb Hoax" case: worse than we thought?|date=2010-03-02|accessdate=19 September 2010|work=The Lawyer|registration=yes}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/may/16/britain-turns-serious-david-mitchell|title=Sacked and fined £1,000 for a joke about an airport? - David Mitchell column - The Observer|last=Mitchell|first=David|work=Guardian|accessdate=19 September 2010|location=London|date=16 May 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/sep/19/nick-cohen-terrorism-twitter|title=Twitter and terrifying tale of modern Britain - The Observer|last=Cohen|first=Nick|work=Guardian|accessdate=19 September 2010|location=London|date=19 September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://jackofkent.blogspot.com/2010/09/why-paul-chambers-case-matters.html|title=Jack of Kent: Why the Paul Chambers case matters|work=[[Blogger (service)|Blogger]]|accessdate=19 September 2010}} and was appealed three times, the conviction being quashed as a result of the third appeal.{{cite news|title=Robin Hood Airport tweet bomb joke man wins case|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-19009344|accessdate=9 September 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=27 July 2012}} == Background == During late December 2009 and early January 2010, [[Winter of 2009–2010 in the United Kingdom|cold weather]] had resulted in considerable disruption across northern England. [[Doncaster Sheffield Airport|Robin Hood Airport]] in [[South Yorkshire]] was one of many airports which was forced to cancel flights. On 6 January 2010,{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/twitter-joke-led-to-terror-act-arrest-and-airport-life-ban-1870913.html|title=Twitter joke led to Terror Act arrest and airport life ban - Home news - The Independent|last=Hughes and Walsh |first=Mark and Jason |work=Independent|accessdate=27 June 2012|location=London|date=10 January 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2010/0122/Twitter-terror-Man-arrested-for-venting-about-canceled-flight|title = Twitter terror? Man arrested for venting about canceled flight – World news – The Christian Science Monitor|last=Walsh |first=Jason|location=Boston, USA|date=22 January 2010 | publisher = The Christian Science Monitor | accessdate = 4 July 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/may/10/tweeter-fined-spoof-message|title=Wrong kind of tweet leaves air traveller £1,000 out of pocket - UK news - The Guardian|last=Wainwright|first=Martin|work=Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2010|location=London|date=10 May 2010}} an intending traveller, Paul Chambers, then aged 28, who was planning to fly to Northern Ireland to meet his then girlfriend (later wife), posted a message on [[Twitter]]: {{quote|Crap! Robin Hood airport is closed. You've got a week and a bit to get your shit together otherwise I'm blowing the airport sky high!!{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/libertycentral/2010/may/11/tweet-joke-criminal-record-airport|title=My tweet was silly, but the police reaction was absurd - The Guardian|last=Chambers|first=Paul|work=Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2010|location=London|date=11 May 2010}}}} A week later, an off-duty manager at the airport found the message whilst doing an unrelated computer search. The airport management considered the message to be "not credible" as a threat, but contacted the police anyway. Chambers was arrested by anti-terror police at his office, his house was searched and his mobile phone, laptop and desktop hard drive were confiscated. He was later charged with "sending a public electronic message that was grossly offensive or of an indecent, obscene or menacing character contrary to the [[Communications Act 2003]]".{{Cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2003/21/section/127|title=Communications Act 2003|website=www.legislation.gov.uk|access-date=2016-03-17}} On 10 May, he was found guilty at Doncaster magistrates' court, fined £385 and ordered to pay £600 costs.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/9359211/John-Betjeman-would-have-been-prosecuted-under-Twitter-joke-laws-court-hears.html|title=John Betjeman would have been prosecuted under Twitter joke laws, court hears|date=2012-06-27|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=27 June 2012}} He lost his job as a consequence. == Response == A number of legal commentators and celebrities criticised the conviction and called for it to be overturned. They include journalist [[Nick Cohen]], who drew comparison with [[Milan Kundera]]'s anti-communist novel ''[[The Joke (novel)|The Joke]]'';{{cite web|url=http://m.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2010/sep/19/nick-cohen-terrorism-twitter?cat=commentisfree&type=article|title=Twitter and terrifying tale of modern Britain|last=Cohen|first=Nick|date=2010-09-19|publisher=[[The Observer]]|accessdate=27 June 2012}} television writer [[Graham Linehan]];{{cite web|url=http://whythatsdelightful.wordpress.com/2010/05/11/prague-1965/|title=Prague, 1965|last=Linehan|first=Graham|date=2010-05-11|accessdate=27 June 2012}} and the comedian and television presenter [[Stephen Fry]], who offered to pay Chambers' fine{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/nov/11/twitter-joke-trial-stephen-fry|title=Stephen Fry leads protest tweets against Twitter joke verdict | Technology | guardian.co.uk|last=Wainwright|first=Martin|date=2010-11-11|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=27 June 2012}} and subsequent legal bills.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/nov/12/iamspartacus-campaign-twitter-airport | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Haroon | last=Siddique | title=#IAmSpartacus campaign explodes on Twitter in support of airport joker | date=12 November 2010}}{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/16945540 | location=London | work=BBC News | title=Stephen Fry says British judges don't understand Twitter | date=8 February 2012}} == Appeals == Chambers lost an appeal against his conviction. Judge [[Jacqueline Davies]], sitting with two magistrates, heard his appeal in Doncaster Crown Court; she judged that the tweet contained "menace" and that Chambers must have known that it might be taken seriously.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/nov/11/twitter-joke-trial-appeal-verdict|title=Twitter joke trial: Paul Chambers loses appeal against conviction|date=2010-11-11|accessdate=12 November 2010|location=London|work=The Guardian|first=Martin|last=Wainwright}} Thousands of Twitter users responded by reposting Chambers' Tweet including the [[hashtag]] #iamspartacus,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/nov/12/iamspartacus-campaign-twitter-airport|title=#IAmSpartacus campaign explodes on Twitter in support of airport joker|date=2010-11-12|accessdate=12 November 2010|location=London|work=The Guardian|first=Haroon|last=Siddique}}{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2010/11/12/iamspartacus/|title=Thousands of Twitter users express support for Chambers|date=2010-11-12|accessdate=12 November 2010}} in reference to the climactic [[Spartacus (film)#"I'm Spartacus!"|"I am Spartacus!" scene]] in the 1960 film ''Spartacus''. A further appeal to [[High Court of Justice|the High Court]] was heard on 8 February 2012, in which the two judge panel of Lord Justice Gross and Mr Justice Irwin failed to reach a decision after initially reserving judgement.{{cite web|title=the Twitter Joke Trial|url=http://www.whoswholegal.com/news/features/article/29377/the-twitter-joke-trial-high-profile-uk-legal-case-social-media-criminal-liability/|accessdate=3 December 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/david-allen-green/2012/02/paul-chambers-twitter-joke-trial|title=Must read posts on the Twitter Joke Trial appeal|last=Alllen Green|first=David|date=2012-02-07|publisher=[[New Statesman]]|accessdate=27 June 2012}} The "[[Case Stated|appeal by case stated]]" was made by Chambers' barristers, [[Ben Emmerson]] QC and Sarah Przybylska; [[David Allen Green]], who acted for Chambers in earlier proceedings,{{cite web|url=http://www.preiskel.com/people/david-allen-green/|title=David Allen Green - Profile from Preiskel.com|accessdate=7 April 2011}} also acted as his solicitor, through Preiskel & Co LLP.{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/david-allen-green/2011/09/-3|title=High Court Date for "Twitter Joke Trial"|date=2011-09-08|work=[[New Statesman]]|accessdate=8 September 2011}} The appeal was entirely on points of law and centred on the correct interpretation of section 127(1) of the Communications Act 2003. [[File:Twitter Joke Trial 1.jpg|thumb|Chambers (centre), with Al Murray (left) and Stephen Fry (right) outside the High Court on 27 June 2012]] A second High Court appeal, before a panel of three judges, headed by the [[Lord Chief Justice]] [[Igor Judge, Baron Judge|Lord Judge]], opened on 22 June 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/david-allen-green/2012/06/twitter-joke-trial-david-allen-green|title=The "Twitter Joke Trial" returns to the High Court|last=Allen Green|first=David|date=2012-06-22|publisher=[[New Statesman]]|accessdate=27 June 2012}} One of the arguments made by Chambers' barrister for this last appeal, [[John Cooper (barrister)|John Cooper]] QC, was that if the tweet was "menacing" so was [[John Betjeman]]'s poem, ''[[Slough (poem)|Slough]]'', pleading "Come, friendly bombs, and fall on Slough!".{{cite news|last1=Booth|first1=Robert|title=Twitter joke humorous not menacing, high court judges told|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2012/jun/27/twitter-joke-appeal|accessdate=27 July 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=27 June 2012}} He also asked whether Shakespeare would have been prosecuted if he had tweeted his line from ''[[Henry VI, Part 2]]'' (Act IV, Scene 2), "The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers". The latter reputedly drew laughter from the judges. On 27 June, the judges announced a [[reserved judgement]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-18607798|title=Paul Chambers 'blow up' airport tweet appeal judgement reserved|date=2012-06-27|work=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=27 June 2012}} Chambers arrived at court accompanied by [[Stephen Fry]] and the comedian [[Al Murray]]. Chambers' conviction was quashed on 27 July 2012. The approved judgement concluded that "a message which does not create fear or apprehension in those to whom it is communicated, or who may reasonably be expected to see it, falls outside this provision [of the 2003 Act]". Accordingly, the appeal against conviction was "allowed on the basis that this 'tweet' did not constitute or include a message of a menacing character".{{cite web|url=https://www.judiciary.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/JCO/Documents/Judgments/chambers-v-dpp.pdf|date=2012-07-27|title=Approved Judgment|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127114900/https://www.judiciary.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/JCO/Documents/Judgments/chambers-v-dpp.pdf|archive-date=2016-01-27|dead-url=no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/QB/2012/2157.html|title=Chambers v Director of Public Prosecutions [2012] EWHC 2157 (QB) (27 July 2012)|publisher=BAILII|date=2012-07-27|accessdate=2012-07-27}} It has been claimed that staff at the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] had been in favour of dropping the case, to the point of informing Chambers, via his solicitor, that they would not oppose the final appeal, but had then been overruled by their head of service, the [[Director of Public Prosecutions (England and Wales)|Director of Public Prosecutions]], [[Keir Starmer]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2012/jul/29/paul-chambers-twitter-joke-airport|title='Twitter joke' case only went ahead at insistence of DPP|last=Cohen|first=Nick|date=2012-07-28|work=[[The Observer]]|accessdate=28 July 2012}} Chambers' MP, [[Louise Mensch]], called for a [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] committee to investigate Starmer's behaviour. == See also == * ''[[Horizon Group v. Bonnen]]'' ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/twitter_joke_trial#incoming-396555 Crown Prosecution Files] on the case, released under [[Freedom of information in the United Kingdom|Freedom of Information]] law. [[Category:High Court of Justice cases|Paul Chambers]] [[Category:Twitter controversies]] [[Category:2012 in British law]] [[Category:2010 in England]] [[Category:2011 in England]] [[Category:2012 in England]] [[Category:United Kingdom free speech case law]] [[Category:Stephen Fry]] [[Category:Overturned convictions in England]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Wreckfest | image = Wreckfest Steam cover.jpg | developer = [[Bugbear Entertainment]] | publisher = [[THQ Nordic]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]] | genre = [[Vehicular combat game|Vehicular combat]], [[Racing video game|racing]] | modes = [[Single-player]], [[multiplayer]] | release = {{ubl|'''Windows'''|June 14, 2018|'''PS4''', '''Xbox One'''|March 31, 2019}} }}
'''''Wreckfest''''' is a [[racing video game]] developed by [[Bugbear Entertainment]] and published by [[THQ Nordic]]. ''Wreckfest'' is described as the spiritual successor to the ''[[FlatOut]]'' series and a cross between ''FlatOut'', ''[[Destruction Derby]]'' and cult 1989 PC racer ''[[Street Rod (video game)|Street Rod]]''.<ref name = "LukeReilly">{{cite web|last=Reilly|first=Luke|title=The FlatOut Successor Publishers Don't Think You Want|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/02/17/the-flatout-successor-publishers-dont-think-you-want|date=16 February 2014|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> A notable feature of the game engine is the use of [[soft body dynamics|soft-body damage modelling]], which enables location-based damage that affects the driving dynamics of vehicles in a realistic fashion.<ref name = "TommyRoberts">{{cite web|last=Roberts|first=Tommy|title=Bugbear Inc. Crowdfunding 'Next Car Game', Utilizes Interesting Soft Body Car Damage|url=http://www.gameskinny.com/io4sh/bugbear-inc-crowdfunding-next-car-game-utilizes-interesting-soft-body-car-damage|work=GameSkinny|accessdate=23 May 2014|date=7 November 2013}}</ref> After a four-year long [[early access]] phase, the [[Microsoft Windows]] version was released in June 2018, with [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] versions scheduled to be released on March 31, 2019.<ref name="Console delay">{{cite web|url=https://gematsu.com/2018/10/wreckfest-for-ps4-and-xbox-one-delayed-to-2019|title=Wreckfest for PS4 and Xbox One delayed to 2019|publisher=Gematsu|accessdate=October 18, 2018}}</ref>
== Gameplay == The final game is intended to include a variety of [[gameplay]] features, including traditional [[auto racing|track racing]] and demolition derbies.<ref name = "TommyRoberts" /> The racing gameplay follows the same fundamental rules as most modern racing games, such as ''[[Need for Speed]]'' or ''[[Gran Turismo (series)|Gran Turismo]]''. The player controls a car in a race or demolition derby, the goal being to win the race or be the sole survivor of the derby respectively. Before participating in an event the player must choose a vehicle, select either [[manual transmission|manual]] or [[automatic transmission]], and finally select either a dirt or [[Tarmacadam|tarmac]] track on which to race. Players will also be able to buy and sell vehicles, customise vehicles, and perform "research".<ref>{{cite web|last=Usher|first=William|title=Bugbear's Next Car Game Early Access Pre-Alpha Gameplay Video|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/Bugbear-Next-Car-Game-Early-Access-Pre-Alpha-Gameplay-Video-61239.html|work=Gaming Blend|accessdate=23 May 2014|date=24 December 2013}}</ref>
The races themselves focus heavily on "vehicular combat", where players have to find a balance between defensive tactics such as avoiding debris or opponents' vehicles and more aggressive tactics such as grinding against opponents and forcing them out of the way in order to overtake them or avoid harm.<ref name = "AdamSmith">{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Adam|title=Impressions: Next Car Game|url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/01/16/impressions-next-car-game/|work=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]|accessdate=24 May 2014|date=16 January 2014}}</ref> While ''Wreckfest's'' focus on physics and vehicular damage is similar to previous destruction-based racing games such as [[Criterion Games|Criterion]]'s ''[[Burnout (series)|Burnout]]'', it follows a somewhat slower and more strategic approach,<ref name = "AdamSmith" /> resulting in a more traditional racing gameplay experience than in comparable games.<ref>{{cite web|last=Duncan|first=Alasdair|title=Next Car Game is now available on Steam Early Access|url=http://www.destructoid.com/next-car-game-is-now-available-on-steam-early-access-269016.phtml|work=[[Destructoid]]|accessdate=24 May 2014|date=15 January 2014}}</ref>
== Development == Development on ''Next Car Game'' began in 2012, and was first announced by Bugbear Entertainment on the ''Next Car Game'' blog in August 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Laakso|first=Joonas|title=Welcome to Next Car Game!|url=http://nextcargame.com/welcome-to-next-car-game/#comments|publisher=Bugbear Entertainment|accessdate=24 May 2014|date=27 August 2013}}</ref> In an interview with [[IGN]], lead game designer Janne Suur-Näkki stated that the game should reach a "feature-complete state" in 2014, with all key features implemented.<ref name = "LukeReilly" /> In a press release published by [[Eurogamer]], ''Next Car Game'' was officially announced for PC.<ref>{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Tom|title=Footage of FlatOut dev's next-gen racing game. UPDATE: Unbounded fun coming to PC and "yet-to-be announced" platforms.|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-02-25-footage-of-flatout-devs-possibly-next-gen-racing-game|work=[[Eurogamer]]|accessdate=24 May 2014|date=25 February 2013}}</ref>
Due to the lack of publisher support, the development team provided early access to the game via pre-orders on the official ''Next Car Game'' website as well as [[Steam Early Access]] and also created a [[Kickstarter]] campaign as alternate means of raising revenue in order to develop the game.<ref name = "LukeReilly" /> The overhaul of the physics engine has caused updates to the game to slow significantly.<ref name = "WeeklyReport8">{{cite web | url = http://nextcargame.com/weekly-report-8/ | title = Weekly Report #8 | author = Team Bugbear | date = 20 February 2015 | website = [[Next Car Game]] | publisher = [[Bugbear Entertainment]] | accessdate = 17 December 2017}}</ref> The game was last updated in August 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://steamcommunity.com/games/228380/announcements/detail/1699433555496548544|title=Wreckfest :: New Hotfix Out!|date=2018-08-21|access-date=2018-08-26|language=en}}</ref>
=== Failed Kickstarter campaign === Bugbear launched a Kickstarter campaign on November 1, 2013 in an effort to fund the development of ''Next Car Game'', with a goal of $350,000 to complete the game, and a stretch goal of $1.5 million to create [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] versions of the game.<ref>{{cite web|last=McWhertor|first=Michael|title=FlatOut developer turns to Kickstarter for new racing game|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/11/1/5056674/bugbear-entertainment-next-car-game-kickstarter|work=[[polygon (website)|Polygon]]|accessdate=24 May 2014|date=1 November 2013}}</ref> The campaign was cancelled on November 22, after it became "obvious" that the game would not reach its funding goal, having only raised $81,722.<ref>{{cite web|last=Farokhmanesh|first=Megan|title=Bugbear Entertainment cancels Next Car Game Kickstarter|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/11/24/5140782/bugbear-entertainment-cancels-next-car-game-kickstarter|work=Polygon|accessdate=24 May 2014|date=24 November 2013}}</ref> Lead game designer Janne Suur-Näkki described the Kickstarter campaign as a bewildering and disappointing experience, as Bugbear had to go to "great lengths" to make the campaign happen due to Kickstarter and Finnish legislation imposing "considerable challenges" on the project.<ref name = "LukeReilly" />
After failing to meet the $350,000 goal of the Kickstarter campaign, Bugbear concentrated efforts on a pre-order campaign being run via the ''Next Car Game'' official website. A playable "technology sneak peek" was made available for download to supporters who had pre-ordered the game, the sneak peek featured 24 vehicles and a single level which the developers used internally to test the game's damage engine.<ref>{{cite web|last=Reilly|first=Luke|title=Bugbear Yanks Plug on Next Car Game Kickstarter|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/11/25/bugbear-yanks-plug-on-next-car-game-kickstarter|work=IGN|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=24 November 2013}}</ref> Following a highly positive response from players regarding the sneak peek, Bugbear released an extended version called ''Sneak Peek v2.0'' to all pre-order supporters. This extended sneak peek included additional features such as new destructive machinery, more dynamic destructible objects, and a "physics cannon".<ref>{{cite web|title=Sneak Peak v2.0 Released!|url=http://nextcargame.com/sneak-peak-v2-0-released/|publisher=Bugbear Entertainment|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=5 December 2013}}</ref>
=== Early access === Following the success of the ''Technology Sneak Peek'', an early access version of the game was released shortly before [[Christmas]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Early Access doubled sales over Christmas week, free demo downloaded over 50,000 times!|url=http://nextcargame.com/early-access-doubled-sales-over-christmas-week-free-demo-downloaded-over-50000-times/|publisher=Bugbear Entertainment|accessdate=29 September 2014|date=3 January 2014}}</ref> The early access release featured two playable vehicles and three tracks, two of which were traditional race tracks while the other was a demolition derby arena.<ref>{{cite web|title=Next Car Game: Early Access out now, free Sneak Peek demo released!|url=http://gamasutra.com/view/pressreleases/207692/Next_Car_Game_Early_Access_out_now_free_Sneak_Peek_demoreleased.php|work=[[Gamasutra]]|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=23 December 2013}}</ref> The early access release was highly successful and received great feedback from sim racers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Why you will love Next Car Game|url=http://gamecrusaders.com/article/will-love-next-car-game/|publisher=Game Crusaders|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=13 June 2014}}</ref> By the end of the Christmas week the game had already sold for more than Bugbear's initial funding goal of $350,000 on Kickstarter.<ref>{{cite web|last=Farokhmanesh|first=Megan|title=After stalling on Kickstarter, Next Car Game finds success in Early Access|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/2/8/5383334/next-car-game-pulled-in-1m-on-early-access-in-just-a-week-devs-say|work=Polygon|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=8 February 2014}}</ref> ''Next Car Game'' was subsequently released on Steam Early Access on 15 January 2014, with special discount prices offered until the 29 January.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tach|first=Dave|title=Bugbear's Next Car Game hits Steam Early Access|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/1/15/5313004/bugbears-next-car-game-steam-early-access|work=Polygon|accessdate=25 May 2014|date=15 January 2014}}</ref> The game found tremendous success on the Steam Early Access platform, earning over $1 million in sales during a single week.<ref name = "MikeSuszek">{{cite web|last=Suszek|first=Mike|title=Next Car Game earns $1 million from Steam Early Access|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2014/01/30/next-car-game-earns-1-million-from-steam-early-access/|work=[[Joystiq]]|accessdate=24 May 2014|date=30 January 2014}}</ref>
On October 3, 2014, Bugbear made an announcement on the game's blog entry for the game's sixth build that ''Next Car Game'' was now officially titled ''Wreckfest''.<ref name="Build 6">{{cite web|url=http://nextcargame.com/build-6-live-official-name-revealed-multiplayer-introduced/|title=Build #6 Live! Official Name Revealed, Multiplayer Introduced|publisher=Bugbear Entertainment|date=October 3, 2014|accessdate=October 4, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Destructoid name reveal">{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/next-car-game-now-has-an-actual-name-282065.phtml|title=Next Car Game now has an actual name: Wreckfest|first=Jordan|last=Devore|publisher=[[Destructoid]]|date=October 3, 2014|accessdate=October 4, 2014}}</ref> The announcement came with a definition of the term "wreck fest" written on [[Urban Dictionary]].<ref name="Build 6" /><ref name="Urban Dictionary">{{cite web|url=http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=Wreck+fest|title=Wreck fest|publisher=Urban Dictionary|quote=Mostly common in racing series such as [[NASCAR]] and [[Formula 1]] (a.k.a. F1). This happens on some tracks during races where the cars are close together and drivers misjudge how close the cars are. Thus, resulting in one big wreck after another. It can also result in only a few cars being taken out of the race instead of seven cars at once.|accessdate=October 4, 2014}}</ref> In the same announcement, Bugbear also announced an eighteen-player online multiplayer has been introduced with new [[deathmatch]] and team deathmatch game modes, as well as a new track and a new car.<ref name="Build 6" /><ref name="Destructoid name reveal" /> The developer also said that they were aiming for twenty-four-player multiplayer for the final release, but will need to spend more time optimizing the game's network code.<ref name="Build 6" /><ref name="Destructoid name reveal" /> It was released out of early access on June 14, 2018. The [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] versions were originally scheduled for release on November 20, 2018,<ref>{{cite tweet|user=THQNordic|title=Wreckfest will COME OUT ON PC on JUNE 14! Brand new release features - new challenge mode with CRAZY NEW VEHICLES plus new paint jobs and quirky customization items. CONSOLE fans look forward to NOVEMBER 20!|number=1002505110549917696|date=June 1, 2018}}</ref> but were delayed to 2019.<ref name="Console delay" />
== Reception == ''Wreckfest'' received "generally favorable reviews", according to [[review aggregator]] [[Metacritic]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Wreckfest for PC Reviews |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/wreckfest |website=Metacritic |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref>
